caption: Beautiful obelisk which was built over 2000 years ago. brought from Egypt a few hundred years ago as a gift from Egypt. It stands tall and proud in this plaza overlooking the Eiffel Tower and multiple historic places around it.

Marvel at the Obélisque de Louxor, a striking Egyptian monument standing proudly in the Place de la Concorde, Paris. Gifted to France in the 19th century, this ancient obelisk is adorned with hieroglyphics celebrating the reign of Pharaoh Ramses II. Surrounded by the grandeur of Parisian architecture and the bustling atmosphere of one of the city's largest squares, the obelisk offers a unique blend of ancient history and modern urban charm. Visiting the Obélisque de Louxor is a captivating glimpse into Egypt's past, right in the heart of Paris.

Raised on this site in October 1833 the Obelisque is purported to be over 2000 years old. Ornately carved with Egyption hieroglyphics the Goldwork stands out from a great distance. The column can be seen in a direct line from Louvre.

This would've taken some incredible work to get this from Luxor, Egypt to Paris. The bottom bit was newly made in Paris in the last couple of centuries. However, the actual obelisk is over 2000 years old, and is located in a giant plaza with two fountains, providing great views of the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe.
I visited many years ago with my father and thought this was really cool to see.

The Luxor Obelisks (French: Obélisques de Louxor) are a pair of ancient Egyptian obelisks, over 3,000 years old, carved to stand either side of the portal of the Luxor Temple in the reign of Ramesses II (c. 1250 BC). The right-hand (western) stone, 23 metres (75 ft) high, was moved in the 1830s to the Place de la Concorde in Paris, France, while the left-hand (eastern) obelisk remains in its location in Egypt. In the early 1830s, Viceroy Muhammad Ali gave it to France. It’s located on the Place de la Concorde, where in medieval times people were executed in this square.

the Luxor Obelisk was erected in the center of the Place de la Concorde by order of King Louis-Philippe. Offered to France by the Viceroy of Egypt as a token of goodwill, the monolith arrived in Paris in 1833 after an incredible epic voyage on the waves
I mean the construction and erection of the obelisque de loucor is impressive but it’s pretty random
Our past will always be linked
Worth stopping by on your way to something else.
Bonito
Good instructions. Unlike those darn Egyptians…
Unimaginable how they managed to ship this obelisk from Egypt to Paris. Wonderful landmark with plenty of history.
Amazing that it is thousands of years old.
Breathtaking obelisk
Historical.

The Obelisk of Place de la Concorde is a piece of ancient history that gives an exotic touch to the heart of Paris. This monument, a gift from Egypt to France, dates back over 3,000 years and is magnificent to admire up close. The hieroglyphic carvings and its grandeur tell a fascinating story, and the contrast with the Parisian architecture makes it even more special. I recommend a visit, especially at sunset, when the obelisk lights up creating a unique atmosphere. A symbol of friendship and culture not to be missed in Paris!

It is a historic gem in the heart of Paris. This more than 3,000-year-old monument, a gift from Egypt, stands majestically on the Place de la Concorde. Carved in pink granite, its hieroglyphics tell the story of Pharaoh Ramesses II, making it a piece of living history in the middle of the modern city.  Around it, the square offers a vibrant atmosphere with the famous fountains and stunning views. It's a perfect place to stop, admire this gift from the past, and learn a little more about the connection between cultures.

The obelisk, from Luxor in Egypt, has a lot of details that make it incredible. Located in the Plaza de la Concordia, it is the centerpiece along with the fountains on both sides. Your visit is almost obligatory.

Real obelisk from Luxor Egypt. It was completely renovated in 2023, and the top was gilded with fine gold. Emblem of Place de la Concorde. You can photograph it from the Madeleine church for a superb perspective

Luxor Obelisk, standing in the center of Paris on the Place de la Concorde. In 1830, the King of Egypt donated this ancient obelisk to France. Its weight is 220 tons. By the way, this obelisk is the oldest object in Paris.

A real Egyptian obelisk, transported here from Luxor! It must have been an epic undertaking. This obelisk is located on an imaginary straight line that, starting from the glass pyramid of the Louvre, passes through here, touches the triumphal arch and arrives at the Arc de la Defense.

An obelisk is a pointed, rectangular pillar-shaped monument that originated in ancient Egypt, and was later passed down to ancient Rome. The Luxor obelisk is one of two that were erected in front of the temple in Thebes (Luxor), Egypt, more than 3,000 years ago during the reign of King Ramesses II. One of the remains is said to still be in front of the Luxor Temple.  There are many cases in which European countries stole cultural artifacts from their colonies during the era of colonial empires and made them their own, but this obelisk is not one of those things; it was a gift from the Egyptian government to France in the 19th century. It seems that it was made. It is approximately 23 meters high and can be seen for free if you go to Place de la Concorde.  The surface is engraved with hieroglyphic inscriptions that anyone can read, whether or not they understand the meaning. In hieroglyphics, there is a grammar that encloses the king's name in a round symbol, and this obelisk also has multiple descriptions surrounded by this symbol, so we can imagine that the names of the kings who founded the temple are written there. .

The Obélisque de Luxor, i.e. the Luxor obelisk, is located in the center of Paris, on the Place de la Concorde. This ancient Egyptian obelisk originally stood at the entrance to the Luxor Temple and was built in III. It dates back to the time of Pharaoh Ramses, more than 3300 years old. It was given to France as a gift from Egypt in 1833 and placed in its current location in 1836.  The obelisk is 23 meters high and weighs more than 250 tons, its surface is decorated with hieroglyphs, which date back to III. The acts of Ramses as a ruler are immortalized. The monumental column is the elegant centerpiece of the Place de la Concorde, symbolizing the interesting intersection of Egyptian and French history.

The 3,300-year-old obelisk marked the entrance to the imposing Temple of Luxor and later the viceroy of Egypt, Mehmet Ali, offered two obelisks to the French people in 1829. However, only one of them reached France due to the technology of the time. . The obelisk arrived in Paris on December 21, 1833

Beautiful Louxor obelisk, flanked by the 2 fountains dedicated to the seas and rivers in the Place de la Concorde. Truly majestic and very attractive, and what everyone wonders is How did it get here?

The Luxor Obelisk is an obelisk that was supposed to be at the entrance of the famous Luxor Temple built in Egypt about 3000 years ago, but it is actually an Egyptian Obelisk that was gifted by the Egyptian Khedive Muhammad Ali to the King of France Louis-Phillip and placed in Concorde Square where it stands today in 1836. . The 23-meter-long obelisk is one of the three obelisks known as Cleopatra's Needles in the world.
Imposing and beautiful obelisk. It is an unmissable monument to visit if you are near the Place de la Concorde. It is imposing and big.
Closed for the Olympics.  I think the use of monuments to promote the Olympics is fine, but having the entire area closed is too much.

The obelisk in the Place de la Concorde is the twin of the obelisk in the Luxor temple and is a marvel far from its original location. It is of great beauty and impresses in the middle of that beautiful square.
It was donated by the viceroy of Egypt and placed in the Plaza de la Concorde in 1836
